Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program of the Chemistry Division, the research group of Professor Guijun Wang of University of New Orleans designs and synthesizes novel classes of glycoconjugates and studies the formation of self-assembling systems from these carbohydrate-based molecular entities. Carbohydrates are abundant natural products and renewable resources on earth. This research aims to advance our understandings on the correlation between molecular structures and macroscopic properties of glycomimetics and to take advantage of the sustainable resource to yield biocompatible materials that have potential applications as light responsive materials or unique supramolecular architectures suitable as ligands for carbohydrate-binding proteins.

Besides being food and energy sources, carbohydrates also play important roles in biological systems such as mediating signal transduction, cell growth and adhesion, etc. This research utilizes sustainable resource as the bases to form smart materials that are responsive to various stimuli including light and heat. The development of new synthetic methods for glycomimetics with desired functionality would enable the generation of novel systems that are potentially useful for biomedicines and biomaterials. The broader impact activities of this project also include outreach activities to expose children to a fun science atmosphere, internship opportunities at pharmaceutical companies, and the multidisciplinary research training of undergraduate and graduate students and postdoctoral researchers (including members of underrepresented groups).

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this research, we have developed several effective strategies in constructing carbohydrate based advanced molecular assemblies, and created novel functional materials that can respond to external stimuli such as heat, UV light irradiation, and change of acidity or basicity. Low molecular weight sugar derivatives that can form hydrogels and organogels have been prepared and characterized. These functional gels are able to effectively encapsulate small drug molecules and they can be useful for biomedical research as stimuli responsive controlled release drug delivery vehicles.

Using commercially available and renewable carbohydrates as the starting materials or the building blocks, such as glucose, galactose, glucosamine, lactose, maltose, etc., we have developed synthetic methods to obtain several classes of glycomimetics which are able to form reversible hydrogels and organogels. Via a bottom-up approach, these glycomimetics contain built-in functionality that can lead to advanced functional materials. Sugar derivatives containing photo responsive functional groups are able to form reversible gels without light. Upon UV light irradiation, these gels can be converted to polymerized gels with different optical properties. These materials are useful as chemosensors and may play a role in sensing environmental changes. We have also synthesized and studied a variety of sugar based branched molecules with dimeric, trimeric, and tetrameric sugar moieties covalently attached. These compounds have unique architecture and show interesting properties due to the restricted interaction and molecular arrangement. Certain dimers and trimers have shown enhanced molecular packing forces but not necessarily correlating to enhanced gelation properties. These compounds were synthesized via straightforward chemical reactions and can be scaled up to large scales for desired applications, this is a big advantage and may have economic values.

Using highly effective coupling reactions including “Click” reactions and multiple component reactions, we were able to synthesize many peptoid derivatives and glycoconjugates. Moreover, a few complex sugar based macrocyclic compounds were also devised and synthesized, though the reactions are somewhat more difficult to carry out, these compounds could have interesting biological activities as enzyme inhibitors. As part of our long term research interest, we are continuing with the effort of creating novel carbohydrate based macrocycles and the study of their possible applications.

Our research in converting simple and readily available carbohydrates into advanced soft biomaterials has impact in materials sciences, carbohydrate chemistry, organic synthesis and green chemistry. These compounds have potential applications as drug delivery carriers and in forming stimuli-responsive materials. We had established straightforward synthetic methods and converted abundant carbohydrates into useful new functional soft materials. The knowledge gained on functionalization of carbohydrates including the synthetic feasibility and how structures influence properties will be useful for other researchers.

The research effort was highly interdisciplinary, allowing students to gain research experiences in organic synthesis, carbohydrate chemistry, supramolecular chemistry, materials sciences, biomedical sciences, etc. The national science foundation grant provided support for research effort of over thirteen undergraduate students and nine graduate students; one high school student and two postdoctoral researchers and visiting scholars also participated in the research. The research has resulted in eight peer reviewed scientific publications and several other papers in the near future. The research team has delivered many scientific presentations in national American Chemical Society meetings and other professional conferences. Those students who have participated in the research effort will have further impact once they enter the work force.

In summary, our research has allowed for better understanding of how carbohydrate derivatives form self-assembling supramolecular structures. The study of photo-triggered gelators has led to materials that are useful as smart materials and for drug delivery; the preparation of glycoclusters has resulted in more complex glycomimetics; the synthesis and study of peptoid and sugar derivatives by multicomponent reactions is unique in creating novel glycoconjugate scaffolds highly efficiently. Several sugar based macrocyclic derivatives have also been synthesized and studied; they may have important biological activities. Using suitable sugar templates we are able to design and synthesize small molecules to function as gelators or have other applications. The discovery of tailored self-assembling glycomimetics that can perform specific tasks is very important for advancing our knowledge and benefitting society. Finally, success in recruiting and educating students at all levels to be skilled chemists in organic synthesis, carbohydrate chemistry, and biomaterials sciences also increase the impact of our research towards society.
